Researchers at the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur have successfully developed a small device to measure the pH of any solution, with preliminary studies showing its usefulness to measure the pH of blood. Unlike the conventional approach of measuring the pH of blood potentiometrically, the device works by measuring the impedance. The device was found to have satisfactory pH sensitivity in the physiological pH range.The feat was achieved by Prof Soumen Das of the Department of Mediacal Science and technology,Prasoon Awasthi and Siva Prakasam.
For more information, you can visit the following link:
http://www.thehindu.com/s...

It's been 3 days since the placement session at KGP has started. On the day 1 of the placement itself, a total of 125 offers were made in 29 different companies that visited our campus on day 1 while 25 students have been shortlisted for the waitlist. Though on the second day the unnumbered of companies visiting KGP has reduced to 26 but still 128 students got offers as well. 26 companies also came to KGP on day 3, however, on the day 3, 97 offers were made.

Till day 3, a total of 83 companies (considering different profiles of companies) have visited the campus and a total of 350 offers were given with some getting multiple offers too, while 60 students made it to the waitlist.

The highest number of students got placed from the department of Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering is 89 while 66 students got placed from the department of Computer Science.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all the successful students and wishes best of luck for the remaining days of placement.

In a bid to attract more international talent, the IITs for the first time are planning to hold their entrance tests in Singapore, UAE, Ethiopia and SAARC nations, except Pakistan next year to select foreign students for undergraduate and postgraduate courses. Foreign students who are selected to the Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) through JEE (Advanced) or GATE exams will have to pay an annual fee of Rs6 lakh per year. According to officials in the HRD ministry, the issue was discussed at a meeting of the IIT council and as per the decision taken the annual tuition fee has been fixed at Rs6 lakh per annum while suitable scholarships may be provided on a certain basis.

Mr. Dolores O' Riordan, Vice Precident, The Global Engagement yesterday visited the Food Processing Division of the Department of Agricultural & Food Engineering. He was accompanied by Prof. Colm O'Donnel, Principal, School of Biosystems & Food Engineering, UCD, Dublin, Ireland.

In order to increase the participation of KGPians in open source competitions like Google Summer of Code, Outreachy et al, Kharagpur Open Source Society has come up with a month long program called KWoC to help students prepare for such events.

Kharagpur Winter of Code or KWoC is a month long program wherin students will be introduced to the world of open source, and trained to contribute to it.Ex-GSoCers and other leading open source contributors would serve as their mentors in this quest.

Go to http://kwoc.kossiitkgp.in... / to register for the program as a student or submit your own project.

In order to increase the participation of IIT Kharagpur in various open-source programs like Google Summer of Code, Outreachy and much more, a new initiative by Kharagpur Open Source Society has been taken for the students of IIT Kharagpur to help them prepare for many prestigious open source programs.

Kharagpur Winter of Code (KWoC) is a December-long online program where the students will get a unique experience of software development while being coached by mentors all around the open source world as well as many ex-GSoCers.

Go to http://kwoc.kossiitkgp.in... and register yourself. The program starts on 1st December. The program is open to all students regardless of their department, course, degree or the year.

Also, if you want to be a mentor in the program, go to the website and host your project.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 4 new photos.
message:
A fire broke out in the Wind Tunnel Lab in the Department of Aerospace Engineering at around 10:00 P.M. on 15/11/16.
The guard control room received a distress call from Srinivasan, a research scholar, at around 10:15 PM. Three fire brigades were immediately called to control the fire.
Srinivasan was in his cabin which is in the Wind Tunnel Lab. He noticed smoke coming out and also heard some sound. He went to investigate and saw that a part of the lab had caught fire. He immediately called his supervisor Prof. K P Sinhamahapatra and the control room to inform about the fire and the fire was quickly brought under control. Nobody was injured in the accident but the lab was severely damaged. The lab may not be functional for a few days and the students are advised to stay away form the lab until further notice.

The Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) have sought Rs. 22,000 crore from the Ministry of Human Resource Development that is needed to spend over the next five years to improve their infrastructure and rise in global rankings. QS World University Rankings for 2016-17 had seen six of the IITs slump down from their positions. The money has been sought as part of Project Vishwajeet, which HRD Ministry wants to implement in order to make the IITs reach within the ranks of the top 100 universities in the world by 2018 and within the top 50 by 2020.
The IITs targeted are Delhi, Bombay, Kanpur, Kharagpur, Madras, Roorkee and Guwahati. Of the nearly Rs 22,000 crore, IIT-Kharagpur has sought Rs 3,700 crore, IIT-Bombay Rs 2,250 crore, IIT-Delhi Rs 2,400 crore, IIT-Kanpur Rs 2,475 crore, IIT-Madras Rs 2,800 crore, IIT-Guwahati Rs 2,695 crore and IIT-Roorkee Rs 5,550 crore. The money will go into improving "research output, faculty, infrastructure and international outlook."

The word career means a person's "course or progress through life". It has proven itself to be more complex and overloaded than string theory and sure has taken away the sleep of many young people.

Carrying forward the series 'aap ki raay', the results of the third poll showcase the factors prioritized by students while choosing a career. Evidently, a lion's share of the students aren't sure about their career goals and are still exploring the possible options. A little more than one-sixth felt that running after money is the need of the hour and is fairly justified to do so.

About 18% are following their interests, ignoring factors such as job security and others whereas about 7% are blindly following the herd. Just the 1% are working on their own startup ideas and have opted out of campus placements. Another 8% have planned for higher studies including options like an MS or a PhD degree, IAS, etc. and have as well opted out of campus placements. More than 17% have an interest in two of the latter options but would still like to keep placements from the campus as a backup.

WorldQuant is back with it's Challenge Autumn Alphathon. The competition is up and running.

Duration : October 28 - December 18, 2016

The WorldQuant Challenge provides interested candidates with an opportunity to test their trading ideas and strategies using WebSim, WorldQuant’s web-based market simulator. Qualified candidates earn points for quality alphas, and these points can lead to Bronze, Silver and Gold status. Individuals who achieve Silver and Gold may be considered for Research Consultant positions with WorldQuant.

The Autumn Alphathon makes the WorldQuant challenge even more exciting through the potential for up to 65 participants to receive a ONE-TIME SPECIAL STIPEND, at WorldQuant’s discretion, to individuals who progress to the Gold level.

|| Important Notice ||
As per the orders from the Prime Minister of India, from midnight of November 8, 2016, Rs. 500 and Rs.1000 will cease to be legal tender i.e. these notes will just be papers from tomorrow.
The ATMs will not function till November 9, and in some places till November 10 too.

Here’s what you need to know:
# All banks will remain closed for public work on November 9.
# Deposit currently used notes of Rs 500 and Rs 1000 in post office accounts or banks by December 30, 2016. There will be no limit on the deposit amounts.
# Exchange old notes of Rs 500 and Rs 1000 at any bank, head post office or sub-post office by showing ID proof. The limit for this is Rs 4000 upto Nov 24.
# There’ll be a limit on withdrawal of Rs 10,000 per day and Rs 20,000 per week. This limit will be increased in the coming days.
# No restrictions of any kind on non-cash payments by cheques, demand drafts, debit or credit cards and electronic fund transfers.
# Rs 500 and Rs 1000 will cease to be legal tender from the midnight of November 8, 2016.
# ATM withdrawals will be restricted to Rs 2,000 per day till November 11, after which this limit may be increased slowly.
# For 72 hours, these places and institutions will continue to accept Rs 500 and Rs 1000 notes for payment:
--Government hospitals will continue to accept old Rs 500, Rs 1000 notes for payment.
--Railway ticket booking counters, ticket counters of government buses and airline ticket counters at airports will accept old notes for purchase of tickets.
--Petrol, diesel and gas stations authorised by public sector oil companies
--Consumer co-operative stores authorised by state or central government.
--Milk booths authorised by state governments
--Crematoria and burial grounds

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur advises the Kgp public to be on a safe side in the next two days and exchange/deposit such notes as soon as possible.
For further details see: http://www.thehindu.com/n...

मीडिया' को लोकतंत्र का चौथा स्तम्भ माना जाता रहा है, और माना भी क्यों न जाए? जब सवाल नहीं पूछे जाएँगे तो फिर बिगड़ते काम काज को सुधारने की आवाज़ कौन उठाएगा या जब चीज़ें सही हो रही होंगी तो उसकी प्रशंसा कर उसे लोगो तक कौन पहुँचाएगा?

कहते हैं विचारों को आप मार नहीं सकते; सही ही है| साथ ही जब तक मीडिया और पत्रकारिता का अस्तित्व बचा रहेगा तब तक ये विचार द्रुत गति से फैलते रहेंगे | आज हम ऐसे समय में जी रहे हैं जब वैचारिक असहिष्णुता आम हो गयी है और ऐसे में ज़रूरत होती है एक जागरूक, बेचैन और साहसी तबके की जो हर किस्म की नाइंसाफियों पर बेबाकी से बोले और समाज के हित में पहलुओं का विश्लेषण करे |

आज से दस वर्ष पूर्व खड़गपुर में जब ऐसे तबके की ज़रूरत महसूस हुई तब स्थापना की गयी उत्साह से लबरेज एक टीम की - 'आवाज़', जिसका उद्देश्य था कि वह कैंपस के जन जन की आवाज़ बन जाए | पत्रकारिता में विचारों की जंग होती ही रहती है; पत्रकार का काम ही है कि वो हर पहलू को दिखाए, और इन दस सालों में न जाने हमने कितने महत्त्वपूर्ण पड़ावों को पार किया, न जाने कितनी मुश्किलें झेलीं और आलोचनाएं तो समय समय पर लगी ही रहती हैं |

खैर, आलोचनाएं इस बात का प्रतीक हैं कि हमें ग़म्भीरता से लिया तो जा रहा है, और इनसे प्रेरित होकर हम लगे रहे, और इतिहास इस बात का साक्षी रहा है कि हमने सूरत को बदलने की कोई कसर न छोड़ी | साल दर साल बीतते गए, पर अपने KGP जनता के हित में हमने हरसम्भव मदद करने की कोशिश की | GC से लेकर प्लेसमेंट्स तक- हर खबर का हर पहलू आप तक पहुँचाया गया |

हम वैसे समय में हैं जहाँ पत्रकारिता में हाथ घुमाकर अपनी ही पीठ थपथपाने का प्रचलन बढ़ गया है क्योंकि जनमानस का उत्साहवर्धन क्षीण पड़ता जा रहा है, और हमें गर्व है हमारी टीम पर, टीम के भूतपूर्व सदस्यों पर, टीम को सतत मार्गदर्शन देने वाले शिक्षकों पर और सबसे बढ़कर आप पर, क्योंकि आप ही से तो हमारा वजूद है | हम सभी एक बार पुनः आप सभी जनों का आभार प्रकट करते हैं और आशा करते हैं कि आगे भी यह सहयोग बना रहेगा |

Continuing the series “आप की राय”,the results of the second poll stress on the communication gap between general student community and office bearers of gymkhana.It can be seen that majority of students demand a platform to raise their problems whereas more than one-fifth felt that officials act carelessly.
Around 31% believed that it should be the responsibility of media houses to organize open house sessions with office bearers where student community could raise their interests.On the other hand,only 10% felt that office bearers are easily approachable and they behave positively.A meager 6.3% say that officials reply to their emails, calls, and messages in case of serious issues.
It is evident from the results that student community is not satisfied with the existing system and the need of the hour is to take up this issue seriously and come up with some feasible solutions.

Carbon dioxide which may be a dangerous waste for the planet is a vital input for Tuticorin Alkali Chemicals for making soda ash. They are unable to get enough carbon dioxide which has been resolved by a six-year-old startup, Carbon Clean Solutions which was set up by two undergraduate students in 2009. The startup meant at  extracting carbon dioxide from flue gases in power plants and use it to make valuable products and even the CEO of Carbon Cleans Solutions said: “We are innovating the carbon dioxide capture so that its price is no more a constraint for conversion to products.” There are about 22 plants which have the capacity to capture around 40million tonnes per year, according to Global CSS Institute, an International member driven organisation. Aniruddha Sharma and Prateek Bumb started this startup and because of their hard work, they are able to develop proprietary solvent which could dissolve carbon dioxide and after testing, it came out that it could remove 90% carbon dioxide from fuel gases. Finally, they got Tuticorin Alkali Chemicals as their customer which is a big breakthrough for the company.

IITs are looking forward to better placements this December as compared to last year in the same month. There has been an increase of about 25%-30% in the pre-placement offers (PPOs) and the companies are eager to sign up to recruit the students. The companies that had already hired students as interns have taken the PPO route this year and are ready to recruit them full time.
Across IITs, IIT-Kharagpur has received 150 PPOs and is inching closer to its last year's mark of 170. The institute is expecting 250 companies to arrive on campus for recruitment, which begins from December 1st. Around 1,950 students are gearing up for the placement process.
Source:- Business Insider

IIT Kharagpur as an institution was founded in August 1951. That makes this years’ batch its 66th batch of freshers. Now that’s a long legacy to be responsible for. To prepare them better for what’s coming and help them maximize what they take away from this place, it is important to identify the patterns where previous batches usually go wrong. As a first step towards getting there, The Scholars’ Avenue spoke to Prof. Sudarsan Neogi from the department of Chemical Engineering for his insights into the same. He had a lot to say from his experience, combining both a student’s and a professor’s perspectives, and here is what we think everyone should know. This is especially a must read for the freshmen who would love to not be influenced by the so-called ‘funda’ that in the first year it’s fine to drown yourself in various activities while your academics slowly fade into the dark.

World Happiness Report published by the United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network ranks India 118th position among 156 countries in the measure of happiness. The Report reveals a significant decrease in the level of happiness of South Asian countries. Unhappiness and stress might lead to depression and anxiety, and the cases of the same could be found in the very own campus of IIT Kharagpur. World Happiness Report, 2013 demonstrates that a large amount of cases of depression and anxiety disorders occur between the age groups of 15 and 24 years. Hence, being an institute of national importance, IIT Kharagpur can play a major role in improving the current scenario and to promote science and practice of positivity for fostering meaningful life. In a belief of exploring the science behind happiness, IIT Kharagpur Alumnus, Mr. Satinder Singh Rekhi along with Director, IIT Kharagpur, Prof Partha Pratim Chakraborty brought the idea of a new course on ‘The Science of Happiness’ and planned to involve the course in academic curricula of IIT Kharagpur. So, here is the full article on "Science of Happiness" to let the world know more about the science behind happiness and the new initiative of IIT Kharagpur.
http://bit.ly/awaaziitkgp...

Computer Science and Engineering department of our institute in collaboration with Research, Designs and Standards Organisation (RDSO) and Service Improvement Group (SIG) of the Indian Railways has developed a tool suite for electronic railway interlocking system which prevents trains from colliding into each other. Researchers said that this project can be extended for further study to develop traffic operation plans. The Indian Railways, through RDSO, has awarded 12 research projects to IIT Kharagpur’s Centre for Railway Research and several of these project and technologies are being field tested after lab testing at IIT Kharagpur.

As the entire nation is gearing up for one of the most awaited festive moments of the year ‘Diwali’, the students at IIT KGP are pouring their heart out for the preparation of their own unique way of celebrating Diwali, the tradition which they call ‘Illumination’ or just ‘Illu’. For the freshers who will be going to witness this trademark celebration of Diwali for the first time, they must be feeling intrigued when they find the air buzzing with ‘illu’. The Scholars' Avenue recently got the opportunity to interview Prof Priyadarshini Patnaik, HOD of Department of Humanities and Social Sciences and Coordinator at Rekhi Centre of Excellence for the Science of Happiness. We sat down with him to discuss the initiatives taken by the center and how beneficial it is for the student community.

The Center has recently been catapulted into the public view with its highly publicized workshop on happiness which saw participation from eminent personality, most notably Ms. Sonja Lyubomirsky, the author of How of Happiness and R. Gopalakrishnan, the former director of TATA Sons Ltd. The workshop is among the first of many initiatives taken by the center. For now , the center aims at focusing on the first year students and the final years who face a great deal of stress while adjusting to the new environment and coping up with the pressure of placements respectively. They have collaborated with Gymkhana and CDC and are planning on conducting various kinds of workshops for this purpose.

Elaborating on the course structure Professor Patnaik explained it to be a short one, over a period of two weeks, and through 10 hours of lectures and about 5 hours of interaction and activities, which will attempt to (a) understand happiness scientifically, and (b) develop a hands-on experience by exploring its various components through introspection, experience, psychometric measures, physiological measures and other scientific tools. He even talked about a survey that was conducted amongst the UG and PG students. The findings of this survey indicated a huge gap between what the students want to do and what they actually end up doing. They realized that this could be the starting point of all the unhappiness amongst the students. A lot of alumni have been included in the project to share their experience. According to them, work life balance is very essential. Extra curricular activities, where people are not evaluated play an important role in having a balanced life. Which is why they even had the science of happiness challenge. Three projects on community service were selected. Two were student groups and the other was a community group .Each got RS.30,000 to do something in the next few months and bring about a change in the IIT community. The center is looking forward to doing it every year and has also planned on roping in CSR and corporate health resources to get a pool of more money.
Next semester they are planning on a couple of electives. "The goal of the director as well as Mr. Rekhi is that by 2017 autumn semester we have a micro -specialization of The science of happiness .So we are targeting that by July 2017 we will have an array of courses, on its different components like positive psychology, self- introspection, resilience and character building . " said Professor Patnaik. On being asked about the career opportunities that the students will be exposed to after taking up the course he said , "We have many students who after going out will start exploring will switch and move into another area or will start integrating the two. Career opportunities and impact of the courses will be in two different ways. First one is that implementation of these in various kinds of organizational and administrative positions. And the other one would be that we could, later on use this micro- specialization to explore further and study deeper into the area."
He also commented on the previous attempts made to quantify happiness regarding which he said, “There are a few tools which may use certain parameters to quantify happiness. These can be tricky and will have to be used with caution. If somebody sees that my happiness index shows that I am unhappy, and that kind of sets the entire ball rolling and that is not how it should be and that is now how it is. That would be against the ground rules set for the course. But in the end , I would like to say these are only subjective indicators . We definitely use a lot of statistics for these indicators. “
They have also planned to expand the outreach of the center and have already been approached by the psychiatrists at Tata Medical who were very keen on discussing the increasing stress levels among students.

The registration for this course has already begun. It is a one credit course and will run from 1st to 12th November this semester. Eminent Prof. of Psychology, Prof. Manas K. Mandal will lead the team of faculty who will offer this course. Interested participants may visit ERP in order to register:
Academic -- Students -- Micro Credit Registration (choose the course: Introduction to the Science of Happiness)

The course can take a maximum of 100 students on the basis of pre-registration and interest. Registration will close on 27th October. For further details students can visit their site :
http://www.happiness-iitk... /

Researchers from our institute have achieved another milestone in their field. They have designed a software that enables those with neuro-motor disorders to access the web, play games, and participate in social networking with ease. This disease occurs when specialist nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord called motor neurons stop working properly and eventually lead to muscle weakness, often with visible wasting.
"For the neuro-motor disorders, we have developed the interface by which they can access web and carry out social networking activities," says Professor Anupam Basu, from the department of computer science , lead researcher and Head and Chairman, Centre for Education Technology, IIT Kharagpur.

Extending its brilliant heritage in biotechnical research, IIT Kharagpur,jointly with IIEST Shibpur and Guru Nanak Institute of Dental Sciences and Research (GNIDSR), has initiated a joint interdisciplinary research in fields of oral health care by signing a MoU on the same. This initiative aims to gather information and tackle oral cancer and pre-cancer problems the people in India face.
Already into lines of conducting stem cell research,which would range cures for many ailments, the Institute has therefore extended its arms wide for future biotechnical research in India and the world at large.
Such an initiative wouldn't only benefit the general public,but would also open doors to advanced stem cell and other research avenues in the near future.

The revamped and refurbished Kabaddi World Cup had a grand finale in Ahmedabad on Saturday night, after a thrilling final that saw hosts India produce top class kabaddi to overcome Iran 38-29. However, some things never change, and India's kabaddi supremacy is certainly one of these. Indian Side considered overwhelming favorites to lift their third World Cup, did so in emphatic fashion. However, doing so against an Iran side that played the match of their lifetimes has an astonishing feel about it.

Awaaz IIT Kharagpur hereby celebrate this victory of our country in Kabaddi World Cup 2016.

With the utmost pain and sadness, we are informing you that Sagar Khurana (CSE/2013/Patel) is no more between us. He was diagnosed with cancer and pneumonia which led to his sad demise yesterday in Gurgaon. Sagar was a great human being of selfless nature who was always very humble in every situation that he faced. He represented Patel Hall and IIT Kharagpur in Cricket and was one of the best fast bowlers KGP has ever produced. He held a number of posts in his hall during his stay at IIT Kharagpur and was a well known Maths wiz and a tech geek in the campus. He was one of brightest students of the 2013 CSE batch who never refrained himself in helping out people. He was a guiding light, a star to whoever knew him and the reason why so many people are crying today is because above all things, he was the sweetest soul you'll come across. A heart so generous, a soul so pure and an attitude that's par excellence. We weep today because we have lost someone who was in all of us. KGP will always remember him as its sincerest and brightest student. May his soul rest in peace.

To express its deep condolences, Patel Hall is organizing a candle march today at 6 PM from PATEL HALL via Gymkhana TO BIDHAN CHOWK in the main building. We request the entire student fraternity and faculty to attend this candle march.

Are the rising numbers of mosquitoes in our campus bothering you? Well, we should be happy that institute is all prepared to help you in case you catch malaria. Researchers at Bio-medical Imaging Informatics (BMI) Lab, led by Chandan Chakraborty and his research team at the School of Medical Science & Technology, IIT Kharagpur  has developed a smartphone app that will be beneficial in the detection of malaria. The present detection and treatment methods are very time-consuming. The development of such an app and technology can help in easy and early detection of malaria. The app has been tested on more than 200 microscopic images of 80 patients and it detected the disease with more than 90%  accuracy.

Indian Institute of Science Bangalore has named second of the prestigious three Distinguished Chairs in Neurocomputing and Data Science (NCDS) after Mrs. Sudha Murty, an alumnus of IISc. Prof. Vasant Honavar, the Edward Frymoyer Endowed Professor of Information Sciences and Technology at Pennsylvania State University, is the first recipient of the Chair. The objective of this initiative is to promote high-impact collaboration leading to capacity building and ecosystem creation in the brain, computation, data, and systems.

Mrs. Sudha Murty, Chairperson, Infosys Foundation is currently serving as a member of Board of Governors, IIT Kharagpur.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur is glad to congratulate Mrs. S. Murty.

Up to 10% additional seats in each Indian Institute of Technology course can now go to foreign students. The 10% intake is in addition to the existing seats available in each of the 23 IITs. Foreign students will have to take the JEE Advanced examination only and not the JEE Mains exams to qualify for a seat in IIT. For MTech courses, they will have to qualify Graduate Aptitude Test in Engineering (GATE). The exams will be held in six international centers instead of just one so far. These countries are Ethiopia, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, UAE, Nepal, and Singapore.

It has been clarified by the officials that an increased number of seats for foreign students does not mean lesser seats for Indian students.

Citing limitations of resources from infrastructure to faculty the seven older IITs namely Kharagpur,Bombay, Delhi,Kanpur,Roorkee,Madras and Guwahati have refused to increase their B.Tech seats as proposed by the government at IIT Council meeting held on 23rd August. However , the second generation IITs namely Hyderabad, Mandi, Ropar, Patna, Jammu will increase their UG seats by 40,50,25,105,30 respectively from next year onwards. The IIT Council had earlier approved increasing the student strength from 72000 to 1 Lakh by 2020.

IIT KGP students have again shown their technical prowess and have made the entire KGP community feel proud of them. This time, institute’s Aerial Robotics Kharagpur (ARK) has carved out its niche in the national arena and they have been the talk of the town for last few days. They are developing drones using indigenous hardware and software which will be capable of autonomous flight, localisation in GPS-denied environments, and tracking and interacting with mobile ground robots as well as other drones, and much more. This technology can prove to be a major breakthrough in various fields like agriculture technology, mine surveying, surveillance etc. Recently, ARK were the only team from India to participate in International Aerial Robotics Competition at Beijing (China) in September.
Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur applauds the efforts of the entire team of ARK and wishes them for their future endeavours.

Source: Business Standard

One of the senior members of the team quoted, "We are feeling very proud and glad after winning the championship trophy. Thanks to IIT KGP for providing such a good platform for showcasing our talent."

IIT Kharagpur and Infosys Foundation,the philanthropic arm of Infosys have signed a MoU in which later has agreed to fund socially relevant projects undertaken by the institute. The major projects being funding of travel (preferably for women) to 'Top International Conferences' and the funding of the much-celebrated research of the Indus Valley antiquity which IIT Kgp is carrying out in association with the Archeological Survey of India. Sudha Murty, Chairperson Infosys Foundation iterated the importance of funding the programmes that will help in the advancement of Education and Culture and said that the foundation was committed to nurturing such programmes.With support from Infosys Foundation, 8-10 meritorious girl students will be selected by a committee at IIT KGP to be sent to top conferences.
Prof. Anindya Shankar, the lead investigator of the project "Tracking the Antiquity and Climate during Bronze Age Harappan /Indus Valley Civilization (IVC) in India Using Isotope & Latest Chronological Techniques (CVO)" feels that funds have reached at right time to maintain the pace of the research.

Inter IIT Aquatics Day 3
Result of Water polo semi finals
IIT Kharagpur vs IIT Madras
IIT Kharagpur thrashed IIT Madras by 12-1 to proceed to the finals.
In another match, IIT Kanpur defeated IIT Bombay on penalties to reach the finals.
IIT Kharagpur now faces IIT Kanpur in the final. Interestingly, the previous final was between IIT Madras and IIT Kharagpur, and IIT Kharagpur came out with flying colours. This year too IIT Kharagpur will play with the host team in the final.
The Scholars' Avenue congratulates team KGP for their stellar victory and wishes them all the best for the upcoming final.

Kudos to those fine citizens of the realm who have already contributed to the Paper Collection Drive! For those haven't contributed yet, we request you again to submit your mid-semester question papers - keeping in mind that even a single paper could help out a large batch of existing and future students - especially with the Library site going down regularly this time.

Here's how you can contribute - Click, Upload & Send.

(1) Take picture(s) of your question paper
(2) Visit http://metakgp.github.io/... and click the upload button
(3) Attach your images in the mail, and send the mail.

Never go to an exam without having had a look at the previous year's paper! Let's all work together in order to achieve this goal.

Have a great week ahead. And awesome Durga Puja hols ahead of that. That's all folks!

story: Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur shared Director IIT Kharagpur's photo.
message:
Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur shared Director IIT Kharagpur's photo.

Congratulations to Team Aerial Robotics of IIT Kharagpur for their prize-winning performance in the "International Aerial Robotics Competition", Asia-Pacific Venue during 23-24th September, 2016 in Beijing China. They were awarded "Best Team Cooperation Award" for their efforts out of total 9 teams from China and India (only our team from India). The team members are: Soumyadeep Mukherjee, Aditya Agarwal, Gaurav Gardi, Kumar Ankit, Kumar Krishna Agarwal, Manash Pratim Das, Sai Ram, Vishnu Sharma

It is a research group sponsored by the Institute through SRIC as part of Centre for Excellence in Robotics. The principal Investigator for the project is Prof. Somesh Kumar (MA) and it is mentored by Prof. Jayanta Mukhopadhyay (CSE) and Prof. D.K. Pratihar (ME).

story: Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur shared Student Welfare Group (SWG)  IIT Kharagpur's photo.
message:
Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur shared Student Welfare Group (SWG) IIT Kharagpur's photo.

Ahoy Freshers !!
Student Welfare Group (SWG) IIT Kharagpur brings the most awaited opportunity at your door. With the motto to assist the students and make their time a happy and fruitful one by improving their skills and attitude, we invite application from all the UG 1st years to be a part of our team.
Register yourself here at http://swgiitkgp.in/recru...
Deadline : October 1st Midnight
For details, Contact :
Vaibhav : +91-8768829412
Veda : +91-7384019601

story: Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur shared Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur's photo.
message:
Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur shared Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur's photo.

Carrying on this novel approach of rediscovering ancient Indian history, the Institute in association with Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur has organized a lecture under the Science and Heritage Initiative (SandHI) titled 'Astronomical Dating and Re-evaluating Ancient Indian Chronology' by Professor Amitabha Ghosh.

Date: October 3, 2016 (Monday) || Time: 5:30 P.M.
Venue: Kalidas Auditorium

Prof. Amitabha Ghosh is Former Director and Distinguished Professor, IIT Kharagpur, Platinum Jubilee Senior Scientist of The National Academy of Sciences India.

You are cordially invited to be part of this rediscovery of ancient Indian heritage through scientific means. Let us trace back our roots which would strengthen our identity as Indians and global citizens.

Prof M A Rege, ex-HoD Department of Architecture & Regional Planning, IIT Kharagpur is no more. Fondly remembered by many students and admirers.

Amherst - Madhukar Anant Rege passed away at age 92, on September 20th, 2016, after a long illness and a long, full life on three continents.

Born in Ratnagiri on the Konkan Coast of India, he had a happy, active childhood. From an early age he loved drawing and painting and eventually earned a Diploma in Architecture at the J.J. School of Art in Bombay, after apprenticing for a year with the master watercolorist Sawlaram Haldankar. In 1949, at age 25, he set sail for England with the help of his eldest brother Vinayak, where he successfully sat the R.I.B.A. (Royal Institute of British Architects) examination and then completed a post-graduate Diploma in Town Planning.

It was in England that he met and married Gladys Sharp on July 4th, 1953, and, after the birth of their first daughter in 1954, returned to India, where he took up a lectureship in Architecture at the newly formed Indian Institute of Technology in Kharagpur, West Bengal. He was to stay at I.I.T. for 14 years, aside from a year's leave in London and a three-year period in Athens, Greece where he worked with the pioneering Doxiadis Associates, after which he returned to Kharagpur as Professor and Head of the Department of Architecture and City Planning.

In 1969 he migrated to the United States, first as a SPURS (Special Program for Urban and Regional Studies) Fellow at M.I.T. in Cambridge, Massachusetts, then as a city planner for the City of Newton and eventually as a planner for the Massachusetts Executive Office of Communities and Development, where he worked in the Main Street Program on downtown revitalization of Mass. cities and towns. He also lectured at the Boston Architectural Center. When his wife and daughters joined him in 1970, he moved first to Brookline, then to Newton, and, upon retirement in 1993, settled with Gladys in Amherst. After retirement he returned to his first passion, painting, which he had kept up throughout his life, filling his home with beauty.

He was a true Renaissance man: a lifelong reader, always with his head in a book, but also an avid gardener. For many years he practiced yoga regularly. He made toys for his children and most of the furniture for his family, taught himself leatherwork, loved philosophical and political discussions, music, swimming, tennis, and cooking, and was a staunch Democrat, making sure to vote, by absentee ballot, even during his last illness.

He leaves behind Gladys, his loving wife of 63 years; daughters Josna Rege, in Amherst and Sally Rege Carroll, in North Reading, Massachusetts; grandsons Nikhil, in New York City, and Tyler, also from North Reading, currently studying at UMass Amherst; sisters Kumud Rege and Sunita Kulkarni, and brothers Prabhakar and Sadanand Rege, all in Mumbai, India; sons-in-law Andrew and Kevin, many loving nieces and nephews, brothers- and sisters-in law, and fast friends in India, England, and the United States. A great loss to us all, but a life well lived.

Beers and Story Belchertown Funeral Home has been entrusted with the arrangements.

Let's hope to see our institute shoulder the responsibility of tackling many other pressing issues and live up to our motto.

http://www.hindustantimes...

आई आई टी खड़गपुर बहुत जल्द 'Science of Happiness' का माइक्रो क्रेडिट कोर्स शुरू करने वाला है। पहले चरण के तहत संस्थान ने दो दिन की अंतरराष्ट्रीय कार्यशाला का आयोजन किया है। इस कार्यशाला में आई आई टी खड़गपुर के छात्रों ने भाग लेते हुए अपने अध्ययन को पोस्टर के माध्यम से प्रदर्शित किया। हमसे बात करते हुए आई आई टी खड़गपुर के Ph. D. Research Scholar,लक्ष्मी कान्त तिवारी ने बताया "आज-कल लोग अपनी भाग दौड़ भरी जिंदगी में इतने व्यस्त हैं कि उनको अपना खुद का ख्याल रखने का समय भी नहीं मिल पाता है। इसी कारण से पाया गया है कि उनको कई प्रकार की बीमारियां हो जाती हैं और जब तक उनको बीमारी का पता चलता है तब तक काफी देर हो चुकी होती है। इसी कड़ी में नींद न आने से संबंधित बीमारियां भी हैं। विश्व स्तर पर रिसर्च करने से पता चलता है कि करीब ३४ प्रतिशत लोग नींद न आने से संबंधित बीमारी से ग्रस्त है। विश्व स्वास्थ्य संगठन के हिसाब से १७.४ प्रतिशत मौत सिर्फ श्वास की बीमारी के कारण होती है और ४० प्रतिशत भारत के लोग २०२० तक ह्रदय से सम्बंधित बीमारियों से ग्रस्त हो जायेंगे। अगर इस प्रकार की गंभीर बीमारियों के बारे में समय रहते पता चल जाता है तो अकारण मौत के मुँह में जाने से लोगो को बचाया जा सकता है।"

क्या वास्तव में विज्ञान से लोग खुश हो सकते हैं ? इसके जवाब में आई आई टी खड़गपुर के छात्रों ने बताया कि उनका सबसे पहला प्रयास तकनीक और खुशी को आपस में जोड़ना है। खुशहाल लोग जीवन को बड़ी आसानी से जीते हैं और बीमारियों के प्रभाव से दूर रहते हैं।

तिवारी जी ने बताया कि हम सभी लोग अपने जीवन का एक तिहाई भाग सिर्फ सोने में बिताते हैं और जिन लोगों को रात में अच्छे से नींद नहीं आती है वो लोग पूरे दिन थकावट महसूस करते हैं और कई बार अपनी काम करने की जगह पर ही सो जाते हैं। ऐसे लोग चिड़चिड़े भी होते हैं और समाज में उनका व्यवहार भी सही नहीं होता है। असल में इस प्रकार के लोग किसी न किसी प्रकार की सोने से सम्बंधित बीमारी से ग्रस्त रहते है और चौंकाने वाली बात यह है कि उनमें से बहुत सारे लोगों को यह पता भी नहीं होता है।

प्रोफ़ेसर अरविंद के पर्यवेक्षण में काम कर रहे कुछ छात्रों ने तीन प्रकार की स्लीप मॉनिटरिंग डिवाइसेस को ईजाद किया है। उनकी पहली डिवाइस बेडशीट की तरह है जिसको उपयोगकर्ता को अपने बेडशीट के निचे सोने से पहले बिछाना होगा। इस डिवाइस में एक विशेष प्रकार का सेंसर लगा है जो उपयोगकर्ता के ह्रदय की धड़कन और सांस की गति को नापता है।अगर उपयोगकर्ता को श्वास या ह्रदय से जुडी कोई भी बीमारी है तो यह विशेष प्रकार का सेंसर उसे पकड़ लेता है और बीमारी से जुड़ी जानकारी उपयोगकर्ता के मोबाइल पर भेज देता है। इसके अलावा इसमें और भी तमाम प्रकार के सेंसर्स लगे हैं जो आपके बेडरूम की हवा की गुणवत्ता, तापमान और आद्रता के स्तर को भी नापता है।
दूसरी प्रकार की डिवाइस भी उपयोगकर्ता को श्वास या ह्रदय से जुडी बीमारी से अवगत कराता है परंतु ह्रदय की धड़कन और सांस की गति को नापने का तरीका पूरी तरह से अलग है। इस दूसरे प्रकार की डिवाइस को उपयोगकर्ता के बेडरूम में कहीं एक जगह दीवार पर लगा सकते हैं। यह डिवाइस पूरी तरह से वायरलेस टेक्नोलॉजी पर आधारित है।
तीसरी प्रकार की डिवाइस थर्मल इमेजिंग के सिद्धांत पर काम करती है, यह डिवाइस उपयोगकर्ता के शरीर के तापमान को नापती है और उसी के आधार पर उपयोगकर्ता के स्टेट ऑफ़ स्लीप का आंकलन कर लेती है।
बाजार में आने के बाद इन डिवाइसेस की कीमत ७००० से ८००० के आस पास होगी और अगले ६ या ७ महीने में डिवाइसेस बाजार में आ जाएंगे।

http://navbharattimes.ind...

आई आई टी खड़गपुर बहुत जल्द 'Science of Happiness' का माइक्रो क्रेडिट कोर्स शुरू करने वाला है। पहले चरण के तहत संस्थान ने दो दिन की अंतरराष्ट्रीय कार्यशाला का आयोजन किया है। इस कार्यशाला में आई आई टी खड़गपुर के छात्रों ने भाग लेते हुए अपने अध्ययन को पोस्टर के माध्यम से प्रदर्शित किया। हमसे बात करते हुए आई आई टी खड़गपुर के Ph. D. Research Scholar,लक्ष्मी कान्त तिवारी ने बताया "आज-कल लोग अपनी भाग दौड़ भरी जिंदगी में इतने व्यस्त हैं कि उनको अपना खुद का ख्याल रखने का समय भी नहीं मिल पाता है। इसी कारण से पाया गया है कि उनको कई प्रकार की बीमारियाँ हो जाती हैं और जब तक उनको बीमारी का पता चलता है तब तक काफी देर हो चुकी होती है। इसी कड़ी में नींद न आने से संबंधित बीमारियाँ भी हैं। विश्व स्तर पर रिसर्च करने से पता चलता है कि करीब ३४ प्रतिशत लोग नींद न आने से संबंधित बीमारी से ग्रस्त है। विश्व स्वास्थ्य संगठन के हिसाब से १७.४ प्रतिशत मौत सिर्फ श्वास की बीमारी के कारण होती है और ४० प्रतिशत भारत के लोग २०२० तक ह्रदय से सम्बंधित बीमारियों से ग्रस्त हो जायेंगे। अगर इस प्रकार की गंभीर बीमारियों के बारे में समय रहते पता चल जाता है तो अकारण मौत के मुँह में जाने से लोगो को बचाया जा सकता है।"

Hey everyone,

In recent interesting developments, IIT Kharagpur is to offer courses on the science of happiness starting today (24.9.2016). “We are looking to the next level... First, it was physical sciences. Now, it’s the study of consciousness,” said Partha Pratim Chakrabarti, our Director.

The courses, to be offered at both undergraduate and post graduate levels, will teach science of happiness, stress management, coping with loss and positive psychology. He also made it clear that while the courses would be available to only IIT students in the first year, the institute will consider opening up the programme to non-IITians from 2017. Here's the full story:-

प्रिय विद्यार्थियो, संस्थान के समस्त आदरणीय कार्मिकगण,
हिंदी दिवस 2016 आयोजन की श्रृंखला में संस्थान में अनेक कार्यक्रम आयोजित किए जा रहे हैं। इसी क्रम में दिनांक 26 सितम्बर 2016 को शाम 1500 बजे से एक कार्यक्रम- “मातृभाषा काव्य पाठ प्रतियोगिता, काव्य संध्या, एवं साहित्यिक गीतों की संगीतमय प्रस्तुति” का किया जा रहा है। इस कार्यक्रम में संस्थान छात्रों, कार्मिकों एवं उनके परिवारीजनों सहित उनके मित्रगणों का भी स्वागत है।
इस प्रतियोगिता में आप अपनी मातृभाषा में एक कविता स्वयं की लिखी हुई अथवा किसी प्रतिष्ठित कवि की रचना प्रस्तुत कर सकते हैं। न्यायमंडल के रुप में कोलकाता से सुप्रतिष्ठित कवि ऋषि श्री योगेन्द्र शुक्ल, काव्य मर्मज्ञ प्रो. प्रेम शंकर त्रिपाठी, सुप्रसिद्ध गजलकार श्री नंद लाल रोशन तथा टाटानगर से अतिसम्मानित गीतकार प्रो. शेष नाथ सिंह एवं श्री शैलेष जी को आमंत्रित किया गया है। प्रतिभागियों के काव्य पाठ के पश्चात न्यायमंडल के सदस्य युवा प्रतिभागियों के लिए सुझाव एवं परामर्श देंगे तथा अपनी चुनींदा रचनाओं का पाठ करेंगे।
हमारे साहित्यिक गीत हमारी सांस्कृतिक धरोहर हैं। श्री ओम प्रकाश मिश्र जी अखिल भारतीय स्तर पर साहित्यिक गीतों की संगीतमय प्रस्तुति के लिए जाने जाते हैं। एक अनूठा आयोजन एवं अद्भुत अनुभव रहता है श्री मिश्र जी को सुनना और हर आंख भर आती है जब वे माँ, पिता, भाई, बहन, बिटिया, पुत्र, परिवार, समाज, बदरिया, किसान आदि पर बच्चन, नागार्जुन, दिनकर, यश मालवीय, ओम व्यास, आचार्य विष्णुकांत शास्त्री आदि परम पूज्य साहित्यकारों की रचनाओं की संगीतमय प्रस्तुति करते हैं।
आपसे निवेदन है कि काव्यपाठ प्रतियोगिता हेतु अपनी एक सर्वश्रेष्ठ कविता, गीत तैयार कर सहभागिता करें। rajbhasha@hijli.iitkpg.ernet.in अथवा hindiofficeriitkharagpur@gmail.com पर अपना पंजीकरण अनिवार्यतः कराएं। विजेताओं को आकर्षक पुरस्कार हिंदी दिवस समापन समारोह में किसी अन्य दिन दिए जाएंगे।
कृपया इस संदेश को अधिक से अधिक साथियों, मित्रों, परिवारों, समूहों तक पहुंचाएं।

We are having a close eye on the development and if the situation doesn't improve, section 144 (Prohibition on unlawful assembly) of the Indian Penal Code shall be imposed tomorrow, said Shri JP Meena, District Magistrate, Paschim Medinipur.

A group of 15 students from the Department of Biotechnology has earned the rare distinction of being invited to showcase their unique genetic engineering skills at the world’s biggest competition in the field — the International Genetically Engineered Machine (IGEM) — at Boston, the United States to be held between October 27 and 31. The event is hosted at Hynes convention centre, Boston. They will demonstrate a technique devised to extract spider silk in an economical and quicker way. This will be the second time that IIT-KGP will be participating in this competition since its inception in 2004.
The spider silk, due to its high tensile strength and elasticity, has potential applications as a bio-material and since it is bio-compatible and biodegradable, it has great use in medical and pharmaceutical industries.
Courtesy: Hindustan Times

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates them and wishes them All the Best for the event.

An RTI filed to the MHRD has revealed that the annual electric bill paid by IIT Kharagpur to the Ministry of Energy & Power Distribution, Govt. of West Bengal, has surged steeply from Rupees 16 crores 18 lakhs in 2011 to an almost double of 31 crores 46 lakhs in 2016. Despite the introduction of several savings and alternative measures like replacement of traditional halogen street lamps with LED, sensor operated lights and installation of solar panels, this sharp upswing whereas can be attributed to an increase in research facilities and functioning of four new halls viz. RLB, LBS, BRH & NVH; it cannot be ruled out completely that the misuse and wastage do not have a colossal rise. The hall and department wise data obtained from the Electric Office unveils that the consumption has increased drastically in almost every hall and department.
Many a times we are seen to leave the lights and fans running while we go to the class; not because of our unwillingness but because of our carelessness. We should always remember that there are still 19,706 villages in our India (Data as of 2015, Census Board, Ministry of Home Affairs, Govt. of India) which remain un-electrified even after 69 years of our independence. Around 12% of our population do not know how does it feel to spend nights with lights!

We, from Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur urge each one of us to please use the electricity and water judiciously and encourage our friends towards the same. After all, every small contribution counts!

What KGP lacks in the absence of high rises, it compensates in the sheer amount of self-motivated student groups or "societies" as we call them, that cater to almost all kind of students: creative, intellectual, managerial or welfare inclined.

You just have to name it and you'll have a group of people actively pursuing it. But the question remains, how do we know what exists? Or, how many groups are present here in our campus?

This is a question that might haunt one's brain as soon as they enter the campus, but it soon fades into oblivion and one might miss the chance to get into a society that aligns with their interests.

We finally decided to compile a one-stop list of all the campus societies that we know of till date.

Presenting to you in an interactive format that might just make you forgive Mendeleev a bit.

The Periodic Table of KGPian Societies, everybody!

https://thescholarsavenue...

P.S: Any societies that need any edits in their respective sections can ping us, or mail us (thescholarsavenue@ gmail.com ) with the edits.
We have only accounted groups that are open to all and are not limited by the Departments and we agree that we might have missed a few nevertheless.

Good Morning Folks!
We hope all your days are running well. The saga of waking up just 5 minutes before class is an everlasting one with consequences that might lead to cycle collisions thanks to some of the new changes in rules around here. But for what it's worth, the IIT tag looms large before you and you might as well put these things at the back of your mind.
But there are some things we do look forward to. Scaling the peak of the most coveted institute in the world, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is everybody's dream. Getting admission into MIT is an objectively quantified pinnacle of achievement.

Well, that explains the rat race we were put into from a very young age, right? It means that we, with our degrees and achievements, are the ones who are capable of following this road.
Or does it?

Here is a story that will shatter such narrow conceptions and hopefully rekindle the fire for 'learning' within you. The most important thing in one's life is to question everything and set upon a journey to find the answers. The present system of education is stuck in a deep quagmire of controversy, but in the end it is the passion and interest of a person that will actually propel him/her forward.

Read about the inspiring story here: http://www.hindustantimes...

SRISTI celebrates the creativity and innovation of young technological students by recognising their outstanding projects with Gandhian Young Technological Innovation (GYTI) Awards. These awards are given every year during the Festival of Innovation (FOIN) at Rashtrapati Bhawan in the month of March. Next year, these awards are due tentatively on March 5, 2017 at FOIN. It is hoped that such recognition will enthuse young innovators to pursue even more outstanding research addressing unmet social needs and set up entrepreneurial ventures in consonance with Start-Up movement gaining strength currently in India.
Any student project that has been completed during 2014-15 to 2016-17 is eligible for consideration of awards.The students need to submit the projects at following URL: www.gyti.techpedia.in .

Financial support is also given to some of the awardees as per numerous windows of opportunity:

Last date for submission of entries is November 30, 2016

You can email your queries to gyti.techpedia@sristi.org ,or call at 9099258492.

Technology Students' Gymkhana congratulates the awards recipients!

Gymkhana awards 2015 - 2016

Application for the gymkhana awards in the genre of technology are invited for

1) Prof. G S Sanyal Cup.
2) Order of merit.
3) Hon'ble mention.
4) Ashoke Mukherjee Cup (Outgoing student who has made outstanding voluntary contribution to the Gymkhana)

CVs should be mailed to gymkhana.kharagpur@ gmail.com by 11/04/2016 at 6pm. All the relevant documents (supporting points mentioned in the CV) should be mailed along with the CV.

In the resumes following information can be included:

*Participation in the GC.
*Position of responsibilities.
*Participation in tech events (eg. KTJ, out station participation).
*Inter IIT Tech achievements.
*Meaningful projects and technical papers.
*National/International conferences.

Regards

story: Technology, IIT Kharagpur added 6 new photos — with Vedasheersh Boorla and Somesh Kumar.
message:
Interactive session with Prof. John Mather witnessed an overwhelming response from students and faculty members alike.

We are sincerely thankful to Prof. Somesh Kumar to make the event successful.

A senior astrophysicist at NASA, Prof. Mather is the recipient of 2006 Nobel prize in Physics. He is a senior project scientist at JSWT, which will be successor to Hubble Space Telescope. He was part of the COBE satellite, which confirmed the Big Bang theory. He was listed twice by TIME magazine; among 100 most influential people in the world in 2007 and then again in 2012 among 25 most influential people in space.

Strengthen the foundation of your thoughts through his precious words.

Date: 29th February (Monday), 6:30 PM
Venue: CET Studio 1, First Floor, Takshashila

A PAN IIT interactive session with Prof. Herald Haas has been arranged on 14th February at 6:30PM. Prof. Haas holds the Chair of Mobile Communications at the University of Edinburgh. He is acclaimed to be the inventor of Light Fidelity (Li-Fi) which was listed among the 50 best inventions in TIME Magazine 2011.

Link for webcast is http://nknvcreplay.nic.in...

Link will be live from Sunday (14th Feb.) 6:30 PM onward. Venue for online interaction is NKN Virtual Classroom, JCB Lab Complex.

Note: The event will consist of a keynote speech from 6:30 PM - 8:00 PM. Q&A session will be from 8:15 PM.
